div.head:
4249. Robert Southey to Henry Herbert Southey, 14 September 1824 Address: To/ Dr Southey/ 15. Queen Anne Street/ Cavendish Square
Seal: red wax; design illegible
MS: Keswick Museum and Art Gallery, 1996.5.333. ALS; 2p.
Unpublished.
div.p: John Calvert asks an introduction from me, – which there was little occasion of asking. – He is quite ignorant what steps must be taken by a youth who wishes to obtain a commission in Deaths body-guard.John Mitchinson Calvert was about to begin studying to become a doctor.

I have had no return of hemorrhageSouthey was suffering from a rectal prolapse. – & am in other respects better. So much indeed does the local relaxation depend upon the general state of the body – that I went up Helvellin last week without the slightest inconvenience, – riding indeed in a cart to Dunmailrase, & from Wytheburn back but being between four & five hours on the mountain. Yet without any other perceptible difference, at other times a walk of a mile makes me feel where my weakness lies. However I take your tonics – eat – drink – walk, & rub down in dressing like a horse.

The PrinterThomas Davison (1766–1831). makes little speed with my history,The second volume of Southey’s History of the Peninsular War (1823–1832). – & I am very poetical at presentSouthey was working on his A Tale of Paraguay (1825). –
